title: How to Make Chex Mix in the Oven

steps.headline: Start with Chex.
steps.description:
Obviously, this is a no-brainer, but remember: Chex offers more than one variety of cereal. For the most variety, go with equal portions of different types of Chex. Or, go with your gut and load it with more of your favorite (and even omit the others entirely). Chex offers more varieties than these, but Chex mixes usually use a combination of: 
Corn
Rice
Wheat

steps.headline: Choose your other dry ingredients.
steps.description:
For a traditional Chex mix, go with pretzels, mixed nuts, and garlic-flavored bagel chips. But this is your own mix, so feel free to experiment. Try mixing things up by either partially or totally replacing the pretzels, nuts, and bagel chips (or even the Chex) with other dry or salty snacks, like:
Other cereals, such as Cheerios or Wheaties
Cheesy crackers, like Cheeze-Its or Goldfish
Other types of chips, such as potato or rye

steps.headline: Add some spice to your wet ingredients if desired.
steps.description:
When it’s time to bake, you’re going to combine your dry ingredients with melted butter and Worcestershire sauce. If you like things spicy, though, consider adding a tablespoon of either:
Sriracha sauce
Hot sauce
Adobo sauce

steps.headline: Decide on your seasonings.
steps.description:
To mimic original Chex mix, stick to seasoned salt, garlic powder, and onion powder. However, feel free to tinker in order to please your own tastes. Consider seasoning your butter/sauce mixture with other ingredients like:
Rosemary
Black pepper
Sugar

methods.name: Cooking Your Mix with One Bake

steps.headline: Prepare your wet ingredients.
steps.description: First, set your oven to 250 degrees Fahrenheit (121 degrees Celsius). Place your butter in a large, ungreased roasting pan. When the oven’s ready, put the pan in. Keep an eye on it and remove it once the butter melts. Then stir in your Worcestershire sauce, salt, garlic powder, onion powder, and any other seasonings.

steps.headline: Coat your dry ingredients.
steps.description: If needed, break your pretzels and bagel chips (and any other large ingredients) into bite-size pieces. Place those in the pan along your Chex, nuts, and any other dry ingredients that you’re adding. Stir them around in the melted butter until they are evenly coated.

steps.headline: Bake your mix.
steps.description: Put the pan in the oven once it has reached 250 degrees F. Set a timer for 15 minutes. When it goes off, remove the mix, stir it up, and put it back in the oven. Repeat for a total bake of one hour.

steps.headline: Cool and serve.
steps.description: Lay out some paper towels. Remove the pan from the oven and transfer the mix to the towels. Spread the mix out so it can cool while the towels soak up any excess liquid. Serve once it has cooled, or seal it in an airtight container.

steps.headline: Bake your dry ingredients.
steps.description: Set your oven to 300 degrees Fahrenheit (149 degrees Celsius). While that heats up, break any large pretzels or bagel chips into bite-size pieces. Line two cookie sheets with parchment paper and spread your pretzels, chips, nuts, and Chex across those. When the oven’s ready, place the cookie sheets inside and bake for 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Prepare your wet ingredients.
steps.description: Place your butter in a large, ungreased roasting pan and stick that into the oven with the dry ingredients. Watch over it and remove once the butter melts. Then add your Worcestershire sauce, salt, garlic powder, and onion powder, plus any other seasonings that you care to use. Stir to combine.

steps.headline: Combine wet and dry and then bake again.
steps.description: Once the dry ingredients have baked for 15 minutes, lower the oven to 250 degrees F (121 Celsius). Transfer the dry goods from the cookie sheets to the roasting pan. Stir them into the wet mixture until they’re evenly coated. Then, when the oven has reached its new temperature, put the roasting pan in. Check and stir every 15 minutes until they’re done. Since you already baked the dry goods once, the second bake may take less time than the full hour that’s usually needed for a one-time bake. The mix should brown like toast when it's ready.

text:
Deciding What to Mix Start with Chex. Obviously, this is a no-brainer, but remember: Chex offers more than one variety of cereal. For the most variety, go with equal portions of different types of Chex. Or, go with your gut and load it with more of your favorite (and even omit the others entirely). Chex offers more varieties than these, but Chex mixes usually use a combination of: 
Corn
Rice
Wheat Choose your other dry ingredients. For a traditional Chex mix, go with pretzels, mixed nuts, and garlic-flavored bagel chips. But this is your own mix, so feel free to experiment. Try mixing things up by either partially or totally replacing the pretzels, nuts, and bagel chips (or even the Chex) with other dry or salty snacks, like:
Other cereals, such as Cheerios or Wheaties
Cheesy crackers, like Cheeze-Its or Goldfish
Other types of chips, such as potato or rye Add some spice to your wet ingredients if desired. When it’s time to bake, you’re going to combine your dry ingredients with melted butter and Worcestershire sauce. If you like things spicy, though, consider adding a tablespoon of either:
Sriracha sauce
Hot sauce
Adobo sauce Decide on your seasonings. To mimic original Chex mix, stick to seasoned salt, garlic powder, and onion powder. However, feel free to tinker in order to please your own tastes. Consider seasoning your butter/sauce mixture with other ingredients like:
Rosemary
Black pepper
Sugar Cooking Your Mix with One Bake Prepare your wet ingredients. First, set your oven to 250 degrees Fahrenheit (121 degrees Celsius). Place your butter in a large, ungreased roasting pan. When the oven’s ready, put the pan in. Keep an eye on it and remove it once the butter melts. Then stir in your Worcestershire sauce, salt, garlic powder, onion powder, and any other seasonings. Coat your dry ingredients. If needed, break your pretzels and bagel chips (and any other large ingredients) into bite-size pieces. Place those in the pan along your Chex, nuts, and any other dry ingredients that you’re adding. Stir them around in the melted butter until they are evenly coated. Bake your mix. Put the pan in the oven once it has reached 250 degrees F. Set a timer for 15 minutes. When it goes off, remove the mix, stir it up, and put it back in the oven. Repeat for a total bake of one hour. Cool and serve. Lay out some paper towels. Remove the pan from the oven and transfer the mix to the towels. Spread the mix out so it can cool while the towels soak up any excess liquid. Serve once it has cooled, or seal it in an airtight container. Twice-Baking Your Mix Bake your dry ingredients. Set your oven to 300 degrees Fahrenheit (149 degrees Celsius). While that heats up, break any large pretzels or bagel chips into bite-size pieces. Line two cookie sheets with parchment paper and spread your pretzels, chips, nuts, and Chex across those. When the oven’s ready, place the cookie sheets inside and bake for 15 minutes. Prepare your wet ingredients. Place your butter in a large, ungreased roasting pan and stick that into the oven with the dry ingredients. Watch over it and remove once the butter melts. Then add your Worcestershire sauce, salt, garlic powder, and onion powder, plus any other seasonings that you care to use. Stir to combine. Combine wet and dry and then bake again. Once the dry ingredients have baked for 15 minutes, lower the oven to 250 degrees F (121 Celsius). Transfer the dry goods from the cookie sheets to the roasting pan. Stir them into the wet mixture until they’re evenly coated. Then, when the oven has reached its new temperature, put the roasting pan in. Check and stir every 15 minutes until they’re done. Since you already baked the dry goods once, the second bake may take less time than the full hour that’s usually needed for a one-time bake. The mix should brown like toast when it's ready.
